ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Review of allocation system for first time applicants)


    1. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether there are further plans to review the allocations of purchased Housing and Development Board flats for first time applicants.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Matthias Yao Chih) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the allocation system was only recently reviewed in 1994. Arising from the review, HDB adopted a queue system in place of the balloting system in non-mature estates. One of the main objectives of the change was to improve the chances of first-timers as they are now allocated a fixed percentage of the flats: 60% of the flats are set aside for them. Furthermore, if they apply for flats in the North Zone where the waiting time is the shortest, they can expect to get a 4-room flat as quickly as within one year.

    The waiting time for those in the queue for 3-room buy-back flats is currently less than two years. And these applicants can take possession of their flats when their turn is due without having to wait out a long construction period.

    HDB has no plans to change the allocation system for the time being.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, would the Senior Parliamentary Secretary clarify whether the prices of flats would remain affordable with the longer waiting time? Would there be a steeper price increase in the near future?

    Secondly, would he also review the transitional rental housing scheme to provide, in the interim, a better opportunity for flats to be allocated to those who are on the waiting list?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, my Ministry will try to keep the flats affordable. No

Column: 1309

doubt prices may increase following construction cost increases, but we will keep monitoring the situation and try to keep the prices as affordable as possible.

    On transitional rental housing, this is something we can review. I shall take this up with the Member further and find out what he has in mind.

     Dr S. Vasoo: Sir, could the Senior Parliamentary Secretary provide advice, particularly to young first-timers applying for flats? Because there is a feeling that waiting time is longer than anticipated. What advice would he propose for those who are first-timers?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, the flats in the North Zone have the shortest queue. For a 4-room flat, the waiting time is one year. These numbers are all made known to applicants. If everyone wants to go to the same zone, it is not possible for the HDB to build flats for them all at the same time. I would say that the applicants should keep themselves aware of the queuing times for various zones and try to make their plans according to their needs.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD SHOPS
(Sale to sitting tenants)


    2. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for National Development what is the objective of the Government in selling Housing and Development Board shops to sitting tenants and whether the policy has achieved its desired results.

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, the HDB launched the Sale Of Tenanted Shops Scheme in July 1992 as part of the overall retail sector plan to improve the efficiency and productivity of the retail industry. By allowing shopkeepers to own their shops, it would insulate them against future rental revisions. With less uncertainty over their operating costs, the shopkeepers will be able to further invest in and upgrade their shops to improve their operations, thereby increasing productivity.

    Shopkeepers who own their shops now have a greater incentive to upgrade their shops, both internally and externally. So

Column: 1310

far, as compared to rental shops, HDB has received about 50% more requests from owners of sold shops for upgrading of their premises in the form of additions and alteration works.

    The scheme has also encouraged shopkeepers to group themselves together to upgrade their commercial centres. The first two retail centres that have completed their upgrading programmes are in Yishun Neighbourhood 1 Centre and Yishun Neighbourhood 2 Centre. Shopkeepers of another seven retail centres have also approached the Retail Promotion Centre for assistance to upgrade their retail centres. A few of these centres, of which one of them is Bedok Town Centre, have commenced the upgrading of the mall.

    The Sale of Tenanted Shops Scheme also provides an opportunity for shopkeepers who do not intend to continue their businesses to assign or sub-let their shops. In this way, more efficient retail operators can take over and thus contribute to the restructuring of the retail sector in HDB estates. Since the launch of the sale, there have been some 3,500 cases of assignment and sub-letting of shop tenancies. And of those already sold, only about 6% have been resold. Thus, the objective of the Sale of Tenanted Shops Scheme has been met.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, since the objective has been achieved, why has there been a slowing down of the sale of shops?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, in the past, the shops were valued according to the area and therefore a single valuation was applicable to many shops in the same area. This was found to be unsatisfactory by some of the tenants and they requested for HDB to make individual valuations. HDB has agreed to do so and therefore valuations of shops will be carried out individually. This takes a much longer time and therefore HDB can only process about 1,500 cases per year as compared to about 2,000 previously.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, before the scheme was implemented, did HDB anticipate that the shop prices would appreciate by 40-50%?

Column: 1311



     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, the price increases were according to market trends, and it is not possible to anticipate to a very high degree of accuracy how prices will increase over the next 3-5 years. HDB will monitor the situation consistently and constantly and provide the valuations according to what the market dictates.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, am I right in saying that the HDB did not anticipate the price increase to the present scale?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, it is not a question of HDB having to anticipate whether shop prices will increase or drop. HDB's job in selling these shops is to provide an accurate valuation for the tenants. Earlier on, the valuation was done en bloc according to the area. This was not satisfactory. The system has been changed. Valuations are now done on individual shops and this is much more satisfactory to the tenants.



     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, is the Government aware that the escalating shop prices, and hence the valuations, have resulted in shopkeepers' anxiety and uncertainty, which may not be in keeping with the original objective of the sale of shops?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, HDB officers keep in close touch with the shopkeepers who have already bought their shops as well as those who are about to buy their shops. Surely, we know about their anxieties and worries. Therefore, the financing scheme has been changed to allow the shopkeepers much easier repayments and this has been announced recently by the Minister.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, would the Senior Parliamentary Secretary consider fixing the selling prices of all the shops now? And if the shopkeepers think that the prices fixed now are too high, they should be allowed to re-evaluate the prices in future when the shops are offered for sale?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, it does not make good business sense either for the HDB or the tenants to do so.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Why not?

Column: 1312



     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Because any fixing of prices goes against market practice. I am sure the shopkeepers would like the prices to reflect market rate. Their problem is not escalation of prices. Their problem is whether the mortgage payments are financed in such a way that they can find it easy to pay.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, does the Senior Parliamentary Secretary agree that the problem is the affordability of buying the shop and the servicing of the instalment payments? If the shop price eventually goes up too high, it would be beyond their means of servicing the repayments.

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, I do not agree that the problem is affordability. The problem is one of cash flow.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, does the Senior Parliamentary Secretary agree that high HDB shop prices may result in shopkeepers being priced out of the HDB neighbourhood which is providing service to the residents? Also, the shopkeepers might pass on the higher cost to consumers if the prices of shops keep on escalating, thus leading to a rise in business cost.

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, 96% of the shops which were offered for sale were taken up. Only 4% were not taken up for various reasons. In any case, we have not detected any escalation of prices. CASE has not detected an escalation of prices in the sold shops.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, what is the rationale for letting CCCs to decide which shops should be sold first?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, the CCC advisers do not decide. The CCC advisers only recommend.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I wonder whether the Government is favouring some shopkeepers by selling the shops to them first and thus allowing them to make a huge profit when the valuations of the shops go up.

Column: 1313



     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, the sale of shops is carried out island wide. Different precincts and different constituencies are chosen for a good spread of the shops. No shopkeeper is allowed to profit from his shop because of favouritism by the Government.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, what are the criteria for the selection of shops for sale?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: After selling the shops, it depends on whether the productivity of that whole precinct, in terms of the retail sector, will be improved.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: How does the HDB judge and anticipate whether after the sale of shops in a certain precinct, the productivity will be increased?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: By close consultation with the merchants' and shopkeepers' associations, with the CCCs, RCs and grassroots leaders.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Does the HDB stipulate what sort of improvements or productivity level should be achieved after the sale of shops?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: I did not get the question. Is it the measure of productivity?

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: The objective is to make sure that the shopkeepers increase their productivity after the sale of shops, and therefore HDB decides. The question is: how does the HDB decide on that? What criteria have been used to decide whether to sell a certain precinct of shops?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, as I told the House just now, shopkeepers of certain precincts or shopping areas have gotten together to propose ways of improving pedestrian traffic, attractiveness of the mall, etc. These proposals are carefully evaluated. After selling the shops to the shopkeepers, they themselves have carried out improvements to their own shops and to the surrounding areas. These are good indications that there will be higher turnover, higher productivity, higher consumer demand and these are factors which will be taken into consideration.

Column: 1314



     Mr Speaker: Mr Low, I will allow you one last supplementary question because we have a long list of Questions.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Yes, Sir. Is the Senior Parliamentary Secretary saying that the HDB will only consider selling the shops if there is a proposal by shopkeepers of a precinct to the HDB?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: No. This is just one of the factors.

Column: 1314

COMPUTATION OF VEHICLE'S AGE


    3. Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked the Minister for Communications whether he will change the present method of computing a vehicle's age to allow car owners to enjoy the full ten years' validity of their Certificates of Entitlement.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member is referring to the current practice of computing the age of a vehicle from the first day of the month that the vehicle is registered. For example, a vehicle registered on 31st July 1995 is deemed to have been registered on 1st July 1995. Its COE would lapse on 30th June 2005. The owner does not enjoy the full ten-year life-span of his COE.

    To give vehicle owners a fairer deal, with effect from 1st August 1995, all newly-registered vehicles will have their age computed from the day of registration. For illustration, the COE of a vehicle registered on 31st July 1995 will expire on its tenth anniversary date, ie, 30th July 2005, and not 30th June 2005 as at present. Vehicle buyers will not have to rush to register vehicles in the beginning of the month, which is the current practice.

    The Registry of Vehicles will consequently adjust the legal life-span of existing vehicles according to their actual registration dates. As a result, COE and PARF expiry dates for many existing vehicles will be extended slightly. ROV will also pro-rate COE rebates for existing vehicles on a daily basis, and adjust the statutory life-span of all existing vehicles according to their actual dates of registration.

Column: 1315



    Currently, due to the present method of calculating a vehicle's age, road taxes of all vehicles expire at the end of the month, either six or 12 months after the vehicles are registered. As owners tend to renew their road taxes just before they expire, the queues at ROV and its road tax collection centres are usually longer at the end of the month.

    From 1st August 1995, the road tax expiry dates of newly-registered vehicles will expire exactly six or 12 months from the date of registration instead of at the end of the month. This will moderate the peak crowds and help to shorten queuing times for vehicle owners. However, existing vehicle owners will retain their current road tax expiry dates in order to avoid confusion,unless the status of their vehicles is changed, eg, they are converted from normal cars to Off-Peak Cars or vice versa.

    ROV will release details of the changes closer to the date of implementation.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, I would like to thank the Minister for his generosity. I would like to ask him whether there are other types of fees which are similarly charged, ie, on the current basis, by his Ministry and its related organs. If so, I would like to ask the Minister whether he would also change the basis, so as to give the payers of these fees a fairer deal and for them to enjoy the full period for which the fees were paid.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, we are doing a review of the fees that are being paid in relation to motor vehicles. If it is possible for us to make the change because of computerisation, we will certainly consider to do so.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, again I thank the Minister. I would further ask the Minister to help me with another matter. Could the Minister also persuade his Cabinet colleagues to do likewise for the other Ministries?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, I do not think they need any persuasion. If it is a fairer system, and particularly with the advent of

Column: 1316

computerisation, and where things used to be done by hand before and it was not administratively convenient to do so, and where it is now more convenient to do so, it is appropriate that we make the necessary changes.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, may I ask the Minister whether this means that we expect to see more changes from the other Ministries for a fairer system soon?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: The Member is not being fair to me. I do not think it is proper for me to commit other Ministries on this. It is for the other Ministries to look at their various systems and I am sure they will do what is fair to the consumer of their service.

Column: 1316

ROAD PRICING FOR EAST COAST PARKWAY
(Revenue generated)


    4. Mr Imram bin Mohamed asked the Minister for Communications how much revenue is expected to be generated annually from the road pricing for the East Coast Parkway and whether revenue from this and other manual road pricing yet to be introduced will be channelled back to road users.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, it is too early to estimate the annual revenue from the Road Pricing Scheme (RPS) at the East Coast Parkway, as the scheme has only started and the overall traffic situation has yet to stabilise.

    The objective of the RPS is not to generate revenue, but to manage the use of our expressways and arterial roads so that they are kept free of congestion. These roads are our major commercial arteries. If they are choked, time will be wasted, costs will go up, and pollution will increase. As expressway pricing is a new concept to Singaporeans, we have started with the lowest possible fee we think is necessary to achieve our objective. We have also kept the operating hours short and started with only one expressway. My Ministry will monitor the scheme closely, and make adjustments if necessary. When the scheme has settled down and is clearly able to meet its objective, we can consider extending it to other expressways.

Column: 1317



    Road usage charges such as Area Licensing and RPS fees reflect the costs which motorists impose on society as a whole - loss of productivity, time wasted, air and noise pollution. Therefore, it is only fair that the revenue collected go into public coffers to be used for the benefit of the whole society, including improving transport infrastructure such as roads, overhead bridges, walkways, bus interchanges, MRT systems and so on.

     Mr Imram bin Mohamed (Nominated Member): Sir, motorists are already quite heavily burdened with the purchase of a car and subsequent running costs, including one of the highest road taxes in the world. Is it fair to increase the burden further by charging the road users? After all, road pricing is a form of road tax. Should not revenues collected from road usage be passed back to motorists through perhaps a reduction in road tax?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, there are two issues that the Member has raised. First, is the question of fairness, whether motorists are being unfairly penalised because of this additional RPS fee. To that, Sir, I would say that it is a fairer system. Because in the case of the road pricing scheme, it is the user of that particular road at that particular time and the cost which that particular usage imposes on the rest of the motorists and on society as a whole, that is being charged for. If the motorist does not use that particular stretch of road, if he switches to public transport, if he uses another stretch of road or if he changes his time of travel, he does not need to pay. So the question of fairness actually does not come into the picture here.

    The second point that the Member has raised, and which I have answered in my answer just now is, where does the money go to? In this case, as I have pointed out, the money goes to improving public transport infrastructure, building of MRT lines, construction of roads, highways, bridges, expansion of expressways, etc. I think the money is put to good use, provided we are able to justify it. At the same time, I must also add that it goes into public coffers so that that money is also used for other purposes for the public good.

Column: 1318



     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether there has been any monitoring done so far on the success of this scheme. In particular, (1) by how much has the traffic along that particular route been reduced; (2) by how much has the traffic along the alternative routes been increased because of the RPS on the ECP; and (3) whether there has been any net change for the better if we combine the two?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the scheme was implemented on 1st June 1995. So it is roughly five weeks since we started. Under the circumstances, it is a little bit too early for us to answer the questions that the Member raised just now. At the same time, in the interim period, there have been some changes in the travelling pattern of motorists as a result of the reopening of schools. In any survey, we need to factor that in. But we are certainly monitoring the situation and as and when the situation stabilises, we will be able to form a clearer picture of what is the real impact of the various plans that we have made, and that is the appropriate time for us to come back to the Member and answer those questions.

Column: 1318

MANUAL FOREIGN WORKERS FROM NON-TRADITIONAL SOURCES
(Employment)


    5. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Labour whether his Ministry will introduce a policy to allow the entry of manual foreign workers from the non-traditional sources like Indonesia, Myanmar, Nepal, Thailand, etc into our service-oriented and labour-intensive industries which are currently facing a decreasing supply of local manual workers and workers from Malaysia.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Sir, my Ministry is of the view that we should not open the manufacturing and service sectors to foreign workers from non-traditional sources (NTS). These sectors have been allowed to recruit foreign workers from Malaysia to supplement local workers. Experience shows that Malaysian workers, being from a traditional source, are less likely to

Column: 1319

create social problems as Malaysian employment practices and social norms are fairly similar to ours. While employers now have to put in greater effort to recruit Malaysian workers compared to a few years ago, because Malaysian wages have risen, the number of Malaysians coming to work in Singapore is still increasing. Compared to the construction and marine sectors, the manufacturing and service sectors have also less difficulty in attracting local and Malaysian workers as the working environment is much better.

    Sir, allowing NTS workers into the manufacturing and service sectors can result in a big increase in the number of NTS workers in Singapore. This will aggravate the social problems caused by such workers and make it more difficult to manage the NTS worker population.
